steps.title: Draw the shape on the coordinate plane.
steps.content: Draw the shape on the coordinate plane. Start by plotting each point of the shape correctly onto the coordinate plane. Remember that the left number is the x-coordinate, and the right number is the y-coordinate. The x-axis is horizontal and the y-axis is vertical.

steps.title: Understand how to read the question.
steps.content: Understand how to read the question. If the question directly tells you to translate the shape by a certain number of units, skip this step. Math textbooks may write the question like this: What is the graph of T ⟨ x , y ⟩ ( △ A B C ) = ( △ A ′ B ′ C ′ ) {\displaystyle T_{\langle x,y\rangle }(\triangle ABC)=(\triangle A'B'C')} ? If the question is written like this, learn how to understand the question. T {\displaystyle T} means translation. The subscripts for x and y mean how much you move the shape left/right and up/down. △ A B C {\displaystyle \triangle ABC} is the shape you are translating or moving. △ A ′ B ′ C ′ {\displaystyle \triangle A'B'C'} will be the moved shape. It will still have the same side lengths and angles; only its position has changed. After translating △ A B C {\displaystyle \triangle ABC} , it will equal △ A ′ B ′ C ′ {\displaystyle \triangle A'B'C'} [2] X Research source

steps.title: Read the x and y subscripts.
steps.content: Read the x and y subscripts. The x-coordinate will determine how much you will move the shape left/right, and the y-coordinate will determine how much you will move it up/down. The right side of the coordinate plane is positive (from 0 to infinity), and the left side is negative (from 0 to negative infinity). For the x-coordinate, move the shape left if it is negative. If the number is positive, move the shape right. For the y-coordinate, move the shape down if it is negative. If the number is positive, move it upwards. You may encounter translations presented as a column vector in the form ( x y ) {\displaystyle {\begin{pmatrix}x\\y\end{pmatrix}}} The same rules for moving left, right, up and down depending on the x and y values still apply. For example, ( − 2 3 ) {\displaystyle {\begin{pmatrix}-2\\3\end{pmatrix}}} represents a translation of two boxes left and 3 boxes up. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Start with your first point.
steps.content: Start with your first point. Pick a point you will move first. Then, count boxes left or right depending on what the value of the x-coordinate is. To illustrate, if the problem said, "4 units right and 3 units down", move the shape right 4 boxes. Then, move the shape down 3 boxes. [4] X Research source Another example: T ⟨ − 2 , 5 ⟩ ( △ A B C ) = ( △ A ′ B ′ C ′ ) {\displaystyle T_{\langle -2,5\rangle }(\triangle ABC)=(\triangle A'B'C')} If the point was ( 4 , 3 ) {\displaystyle (4,3)} , move the point to the left 2 boxes. You are now at ( 2 , 3 ) {\displaystyle (2,3)} . Then, move the point up 5 boxes. The translated point is ( 2 , 8 ) {\displaystyle (2,8)} Label the new shape's points with ' (prime) symbols. So, A {\displaystyle A} becomes A ′ {\displaystyle A'} . Repeat this process for every point of the original shape.

steps.title: Start with your first point.
steps.content: Start with your first point. Pick a point you will move first. Add the x-subscript (or x value of the column vector) to your original x-coordinate, and the y-subscript (or y value of the column vector) to your original y-coordinate. You will now have the coordinate of your translated point. [6] X Research source The same example from above: T ⟨ − 2 , 5 ⟩ ( △ A B C ) = ( △ A ′ B ′ C ′ ) {\displaystyle T_{\langle -2,5\rangle }(\triangle ABC)=(\triangle A'B'C')} If the point was ( 4 , 3 ) {\displaystyle (4,3)} , add − 2 {\displaystyle -2} to the 4 {\displaystyle 4} . 4 + ( − 2 ) {\displaystyle 4+(-2)} equals 4 − 2 ; x = 2. {\displaystyle 4-2;x=2.} Next, add 5 {\displaystyle 5} to your y-coordinate, which is now ( 2 , 3 ) {\displaystyle (2,3)} . 3 + 5 = 8 ; y = 8 {\displaystyle 3+5=8;y=8} . The translated coordinate is ( 2 , 8 ) {\displaystyle (2,8)} Label the new shape's points with ' (prime) symbols. So, A {\displaystyle A} becomes A ′ {\displaystyle A'} . Repeat this process for every point of the original shape.
